urn:contentItem:6GH3-KJ33-RTB6-G1HR-00000-00Councils seek to reduce climate-change risk2025-08-16T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T07:00:52ZLexisNexisBUSINESSLocal GovernmentPg. 13Councils seek to reduce climate-change risk

Deadly heatwaves, increased flooding, rising seas and damaged infrastructure are some of the climate-change perils the winner of a current tender covering nine inner-metropolitan councils will need to grapple with.

M9 - an alliance of the Melbourne, Darebin, Hobsons Bay, Maribyrnong, Merri-Bek, Moonee Valley, Port Phillip, Stonnington and Yarra councils - is seeking a consultant to manage a climate-change resilience planning project.

"Damage from climate change is set to impact the billions of dollars worth of assets that local government manage," M9 tender documents say. "Reducing the physical impacts of climate risk is dependent on improved planning and management of assets."

The Resilient Asset Management and Investment Project (RAMI) aims to find ways to address climate resilience challenges while reducing costs. A major objective is to "deliver a tool" that can be embedded into existing council systems and processes and applied to nine high-risk flood sites (one per council) to "build internal capacity using effective change management".

The M9 alliance incorporates some of the highest flood-risk areas in the metropolitan area, including Maribyrnong, where devastating floods in October 2022 hit 572 homes, and 47 villas in the Rivervue retirement village.

The Maribyrnong River has flooded roughly every 10-20 years since 1871, hitting what are now high-density suburbs like Footscray, Yarraville, Moonee Ponds, Maribyrnong, Flemington, Avondale Heights and Aberfeldie.

Rising seas are another danger facing M9 councils. For example, more than 16,000 properties in Melbourne's Southbank are at high risk of damage from sea-level rises and storm surges within 17 years, according to a major report released in 2022. The Victorian Marine and Coastal Council report - which includes research from The University of Melbourne and Climate Risk - warns the total Victorian damage bill could reach

$442 billion by 2100.

The flooding would cause extensive damage to residential and commercial properties as well as transport routes. Port Melbourne and Australia's biggest urban development project at Fishermans Bend are among the M9 areas at risk.

Tom Kompas, University of Melbourne environmental economics professor and lead researcher, said both his team and Climate Risk reached similar conclusions, despite using different models.

He hoped the research would help guide authorities in determining where properties should be built in future.

"If you build a house now in the wrong area you're going to have trouble," he said. "At some point for some communities, retreat is the only option."

Other studies show that rising heat is the greatest problem facing every M9 council. Killer heatwaves are responsible for more deaths each year than all other types of disaster combined, and scientists say that more resilient housing and infrastructure is needed.

The latest projections from scientists at the CSIRO show that temperatures in Melbourne could reach an unprecedented 50 degrees within decades.

Activities

Tetra Tech, Inc. is a leading global provider of consulting and engineering services, headquartered in Pasadena, California. The company primarily generates its revenue from two core segments: Government Services Group (GSG) and Commercial/International Services Group (CIG). The GSG, which accounts for the largest portion of revenue, focuses on providing technical services to U.S. federal, state, and local government agencies, including water resource management, environmental restoration, and infrastructure support. The CIG segment serves commercial clients and international markets with similar expertise in water, environment, and energy solutions. Among its fastest-growing areas, Tetra Tech has seen significant expansion in renewable energy projects, particularly in wind and solar infrastructure, as well as climate resilience and disaster recovery services, driven by increasing global demand for sustainable solutions. With a strong commitment to innovation, Tetra Tech continues to address complex challenges in water, environment, and infrastructure for a diverse client base worldwide. It is the NASDAQ's 5th largest Consumer product/services company by market capitalisation.

TETRA TECH PRESS RELEASES AND CORPORATE WIRE

August 01: Tetra Tech quarterly dividends steady

Tetra Tech today announced a quarterly dividend of 6.50c per share for Q3/2025; unchanged from the previous quarter (Q2/2025) dividend of 6.50c. The ex-dividend date is Friday, August 15, 2025 and the record date is Friday, August 15, 2025 and it is payable on Friday, August 29. Total dividends per share paid in the 12 months ended August 01 were 19.26c. This reflects actual dividend yield of 0.5% at the last price of $36.74.

urn:contentItem:6GF0-5X33-S7R0-925J-00000-00Farmers get on front foot in evolving war against weeds2025-08-06T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T07:00:52ZLexisNexisNews7Farmers get on front foot in evolving war against weeds

Australian grain and cotton growers are proving weeds can be beaten, investing significantly in strategies to help improve their control.

Managing weeds costs the grain and cotton industries an estimated $4.4 billion per year, a report from Australia's national science agency CSIRO has found.

Despite the large expenditure, growers are reaping the rewards. The impact of crop yield has fallen from 2.8 million tonnes in 2016 to 1.2 million tonnes in 2025, which translates into higher production and income.

"Weed control remains one of the biggest annual costs for growers, but the investment is paying off," CSIRO research scientist Rick Llewellyn said.

"By staying ahead of the weed seed bank, resistance and adopting smarter, more targeted practices, growers are protecting long-term profitability and enabling flexibility in their system."

Weed management demands being on the front foot and strategic planning, central west NSW fifth-generation farmer Richie Quigley said.

"We spend a huge amount of time and money combating weeds and there is a lot of strategy behind it to make sure we are using all the tools in the toolbox," he told AAP.

"They are becoming much harder to kill and control and we have to be at the top of our game to be able to manage them."

Growers are combining pre-emergent herbicides, harvest weed seed control, crop rotation and new precision spraying technologies in their management strategy.

Effective weed control was critical in adapting to climate change, CSIRO technical officer Jackie Ouzman said.

"Climate variability does pose significant challenges to growers but they are responding really positively to these challenges," she said.

"Growers are well positioned to cope with more variable climate, with the practices they're currently doing."

The most costly weeds to manage are ryegrass, brome grass, sow thistle, wild radish and wild oats, while the costliest fallow weeds in grain production at a national level are melons, heliotrope and fleabane.

The CSIRO study shows the need for continued investment in weed management research to unlock productivity, climate resilience and sustainable land use.

"The only reason we're not seeing widespread yield losses from weeds today is because of years of sustained research and grower innovation," Dr Llewellyn said.

"This is a quiet success story, but it's a battle where you can't pause."

Activities

Tetra Tech, Inc. is a leading global provider of consulting and engineering services, headquartered in Pasadena, California. The company primarily generates its revenue from two core segments: Government Services Group (GSG) and Commercial/International Services Group (CIG). The GSG, which accounts for the largest portion of revenue, focuses on providing technical services to U.S. federal, state, and local government agencies, including water resource management, environmental restoration, and infrastructure support. The CIG segment serves commercial clients and international markets with similar expertise in water, environment, and energy solutions. Among its fastest-growing areas, Tetra Tech has seen significant expansion in renewable energy projects, particularly in wind and solar infrastructure, as well as climate resilience and disaster recovery services, driven by increasing global demand for sustainable solutions. With a strong commitment to innovation, Tetra Tech continues to address complex challenges in water, environment, and infrastructure for a diverse client base worldwide. It is the NASDAQ's 5th largest Consumer product/services company by market capitalisation.

urn:contentItem:6G0T-VF13-RWGS-91DK-00000-00Climate change threats outlined for growing Lake Macquarie communities2025-06-10T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T07:00:52ZLexisNexisClimate change threats outlined for growing Lake Macquarie communitiesJosh Leeson

The risk of bushfires, floods and lake water rises are expected to grow dramatically in coming decades.

The northwestern corner of Lake Macquarie is expected to see its bushfire risk grow by 130 per cent later this century and experience a 19.7 per cent increase in rainfall and a 0.4-metre rise to the lake water level by 2050, according to local government modelling.

Lake Macquarie City Council is expected to place its draft Teralba to Toronto (T2T) Climate Resilience Plan on exhibition after Tuesday night's Standing Committee Meeting at the Windale Hub.

In the draft climate resilience plan, the council said the vision was that "the nine lakeside suburbs from Teralba to Toronto will build climate resilience by proactively planning and preparing for, and adapting to, current and emerging climate-related hazards".

The report makes for sobering reading as the impact of global climate change is predicted to create serious challenges for the council and residents in the suburbs of Teralba, Booragul, Marmong Point, Woodrising, Bolton Point, Fennell Bay, Fassifern, Blackalls Park and Toronto.

The council has previously adopted the Marks Point and Belmont South Local Adaptation Plan and the Pelican, Blacksmiths, Swansea, Swansea Heads and Caves Beach Local Adaptation Plan.

These plans identified tidal inundation, sea level rise and storm surges as the biggest risks to ratepayer property and public infrastructure in eastern Lake Macquarie.

However, suburbs between Teralba and Toronto also face the threat of increasingly frequent bushfires due to rises in temperature.

According to the council's report, the T2T area will experience a 45 per cent increase in severe fire weather days by 2030 and a 130 per cent rise by 2090, compared to 1995.

Toronto (533), Blackalls Park (299) and Bolton Point (312) are identified as the suburbs with the most homes on fire-prone land.

Compared to 1995, the extreme rainfall each year is expected to increase by 10 per cent by 2030 and 19.7 per cent by 2050.

Five out of the nine T2T suburbs are tipped to have houses impacted by flooding, with Blackalls Park (110), Toronto (92) and Teralba (29) boasting the most at risk.

Liberal West Ward councillor Jason Pauling urged all residents in the T2T suburbs to read the climate resilience plan and contribute when it's on public exhibition.

"The key bit I'd be highlighting is residents of Teralba, Blackalls Park, and particularly Toronto, are listed highest for exposure to a number of elements like flooding, lake level rise, bushfire, and social and economic [problems]," Cr Pauling said.

The lake water level is expected to rise by 0.4 metres in 2050 from 1990 records and by 0.9m in 2100, causing low-lying areas to be permanently inundated.

Blackalls Park (168), Toronto (144) and Teralba (54) would have the most homes affected by the predicted lake water level rise.

The western side of Lake Macquarie experiences an annual average of 12 extreme heat days when temperatures reach or exceed 35 degrees.

That is projected to increase to 17 days per year by 2030 and 27 days per year by 2090.

At the moment, 9.1 per cent of Lake Macquarie's population of 214,000 residents live in the suburbs between Teralba and Toronto.

However, that is expected to rise with suburbs like Teralba and Fennell Bay identified for residential growth over the next 20 years.

Cr Pauling said he would like to see more detail about how the council can actively prepare for these predicted climate issues.

"Everyone wants a resilient community that thrives, and the key is getting the balance right between restrictive practices, financial impact and appropriate safety and resilience," Cr Pauling said.

Lake Macquarie councillors will take a close look at the impact of climate change on the city at Tuesday's meeting. Picture by Max Mason-Hubers

   "We spend a huge amount of time and money combating weeds and there is a lot of strategy behind it to make sure we are using all the tools in the toolbox," he told AAP.
   "They are becoming much harder to kill and control and we have to be at the top of our game to be able to manage them."
   Growers are combining pre-emergent herbicides, harvest weed seed control, crop rotation and new precision spraying technologies in their management strategy.
   Effective weed control was critical in adapting to climate change, CSIRO technical officer Jackie Ouzman said.
   "Climate variability does pose significant challenges to growers but they are responding really positively to these challenges," she said.
   "Growers are well positioned to cope with more variable climate, with the practises they're currently doing."
   The most costly weeds to manage are ryegrass, brome grass, sow thistle, wild radish and wild oats, while the costliest fallow weeds in grain production at a national level are melons, heliotrope and fleabane.
   The CSIRO study shows the need for continued investment in weed management research to unlock productivity, climate resilience and sustainable land use.
   "The only reason we're not seeing widespread yield losses from weeds today is because of years of sustained research and grower innovation," Dr Llewellyn said.
   "This is a quiet success story, but it's a battle where you can't pause - the weed challenge keeps evolving and demanding new solutions."

urn:contentItem:6G9X-9HP3-RRRX-R3N8-00000-00Half of island's residents want to live here2025-07-22T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T07:00:52ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 4Half of island's residents want to live hereBrendan Kearns

More than half of the citizens of the Pacific nation of Tuvalu have applied for a visa to permanently migrate to Australia.

Just over a month ago, Australia opened the The Falepili Mobility Pathway ballot, a program to provide citizens of the tiny island nation of Tuvalu a permanent migration pathway to Australia.

The country has a population of just 10,643, while at least 5157 of them entered the lottery - more than half of the nation's people.

This was through 1466 registrations, with many of the people being included as family members on applications.

The ballot, which closed on Friday, randomly selected up to 280 people each year to apply for the visa.

It is open to all Tuvalu citizens, regardless of age, and visa holders do not need to gain employment in Australia before applying. If the pace of applications keeps up, it could mean the entire population of Tuvalu could live in Australia within 40 years.

Selections for the ballot will take place between July 25 and January 25 next year.

The scheme allows successful applicants to live, work and study anywhere in Australia indefinitely, sponsor relatives to also migrate to Australia, and apply for citizenship once eligible. The population of the island nation is one of the world's most exposed to the effects of climate change, with this program providing a path to flee as the impacts worsen. The pathway is part of the Australia-Tuvalu Falepili Union that both countries signed on August 28, 2024, part of which is to build climate resilience.

urn:contentItem:6GDS-VR33-RTWS-T1SK-00000-00FED:Farmers get on front foot in evolving war against weeds2025-08-05T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T07:00:52ZLexisNexisFED:Farmers get on front foot in evolving war against weedsSYDNEY Aug 5

  Australian grain and cotton growers are proving weeds can be beaten, investing significantly in strategies to help improve their control.
   Managing weeds costs the grain and cotton industries an estimated $4.4 billion per year, a report from Australia's national science agency CSIRO has found.


   Despite the large expenditure, growers are reaping the rewards. The impact of crop yield has fallen from 2.8 million tonnes in 2016 to 1.2 million tonnes in 2025, which translates into higher production and income.
   "Weed control remains one of the biggest annual costs for growers, but the investment is paying off," CSIRO research scientist Rick Llewellyn said.
   "By staying ahead of the weed seed bank, resistance and adopting smarter, more targeted practices, growers are protecting long-term profitability and enabling flexibility in their system."
   Weed management demands being on the front foot and strategic planning, central west NSW fifth-generation farmer Richie Quigley said.
   "We spend a huge amount of time and money combating weeds and there is a lot of strategy behind it to make sure we are using all the tools in the toolbox," he told AAP.
   "They are becoming much harder to kill and control and we have to be at the top of our game to be able to manage them."
   Growers are combining pre-emergent herbicides, harvest weed seed control, crop rotation and new precision spraying technologies in their management strategy.
   Effective weed control was critical in adapting to climate change, CSIRO technical officer Jackie Ouzman said.
   "Climate variability does pose significant challenges to growers but they are responding really positively to these challenges," she said.
   "Growers are well positioned to cope with more variable climate, with the practises they're currently doing."
   The most costly weeds to manage are ryegrass, brome grass, sow thistle, wild radish and wild oats, while the costliest fallow weeds in grain production at a national level are melons, heliotrope and fleabane.
   The CSIRO study shows the need for continued investment in weed management research to unlock productivity, climate resilience and sustainable land use.
   "The only reason we're not seeing widespread yield losses from weeds today is because of years of sustained research and grower innovation," Dr Llewellyn said.
   "This is a quiet success story, but it's a battle where you can't pause - the weed challenge keeps evolving and demanding new solutions."

Activities

Tetra Tech, Inc. is a leading global provider of consulting and engineering services, headquartered in Pasadena, California. The company primarily generates its revenue from two core segments: Government Services Group (GSG) and Commercial/International Services Group (CIG). The GSG, which accounts for the largest portion of revenue, focuses on providing technical services to U.S. federal, state, and local government agencies, including water resource management, environmental restoration, and infrastructure support. The CIG segment serves commercial clients and international markets with similar expertise in water, environment, and energy solutions. Among its fastest-growing areas, Tetra Tech has seen significant expansion in renewable energy projects, particularly in wind and solar infrastructure, as well as climate resilience and disaster recovery services, driven by increasing global demand for sustainable solutions. With a strong commitment to innovation, Tetra Tech continues to address complex challenges in water, environment, and infrastructure for a diverse client base worldwide. It is the NASDAQ's 5th largest Consumer product/services company by market capitalisation.

urn:contentItem:6G64-76Y3-RRRD-32PP-00000-00WEEKLY RECAP: UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA SANTA CRUZ NEWS THIS PAST WEEK JUL 03, 20252025-07-04T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T07:00:52ZLexisNexisWEEKLY RECAP: UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA SANTA CRUZ NEWS THIS PAST WEEK JUL 03, 2025

+ UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA SANTA CRUZ [8 Press Releases]

+ UC SANTA CRUZ ALUMNI AT THE FOREFRONT OF ALOPECIA RESEARCH AND ADVOCACY

Key takeaways Nicole Friedland (Merrill '89, community studies) is the President and CEO of the National Alopecia Areata Foundation. Brett King (Crown '92, chemistry) is a renowned dermatologist who discovered that a class of medicines called Janus kinase (JAK) inhibitors were effective for treatment of alopecia areata and other disorders.

Source: Company Website

+ EVENTS CALENDAR: UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA SANTA CRUZ FACULTY AND FELLOWS AMONG GLOBAL LEADERS IN ATTENDANCE AT 2025 UNITED NATIONS OCEAN CONFERENCE

On June 9-13, some of the world's top leaders in marine science and protection convened in Nice, France for the third United Nations Ocean Conference (UNOC). University of California, Santa Cruz and the Center for Coastal Climate Resilience (CCCR) had strong representation at UNOC and the opening Blue Economy Finance Forum (BEFF) in Monaco, with several fellows and faculty attending to share highlights from their research and engage in global dialogues about climate adaptation, mitigation and the future of our coasts.

Source: Company Website

+ UC SANTA CRUZ ALUMNI LEADING LOCAL NONPROFITS: THE VOLUNTEER CENTER

Santa Cruz County is home to over a thousand nonprofit organizations, groups dedicated to strengthening the community, supporting those in need, and making a meaningful impact. Many of these nonprofits have roots that trace back to University of California Santa Cruz alumni, who played pivotal roles in launching and shaping their missions. Among those are one of Santa Cruz's most recognizable names-the Volunteer Center of Santa Cruz County -which shares ties with many UC Santa Cruz alumni and is integral to the community's health and well-being.

Source: Company Website

+ UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA SANTA CRUZ: USING TECHNOLOGY AND GAMES TO BUILD CLIMATE RESILIENT COMMUNITIES

Technology enhances resilience by expanding access to information and strengthening community networks. Hirsch's research highlights the role of digital tools-like social media and messaging apps-in building preparedness and connecting people to local resources.

Source: Company Website

+ UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA SANTA CRUZ: UNDERSTANDING THE INFLUENCES OF TECHNOLOGY AND ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT ON GENOCIDE RISK

The rise of social media in recent decades has brought with it a steady drumbeat of warnings from experts around the world. The unchecked spread of disinformation, propaganda, and hate speech on these platforms can fuel the darkest of human impulses. New research led by politics and legal studies double-major John Bentley shows how the roll-out of social media in developing countries could actually increase the risk of genocide.

Source: Company Website

+ UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA SANTA CRUZ: THE FUTURE OF CLIMATE: THE CENTER FOR COASTAL CLIMATE RESILIENCE SUPPORTS A CRITICAL WAVE OF RESEARCH FELLOWS

As the science community's focus on climate change and adaptation continues to grow, research fellows are playing a pivotal role in driving the innovation needed to build greater resilience in the face of climate change. The University of California, Santa Cruz Center for Coastal Climate Resilience has made a major commitment in the past 2.5 years to support and bring to campus more than 60 Fellows at all levels from early career grad students to senior fellows. Fellows cover programs across campus and include business leaders, indigenous diplomats, graduate students in Coastal Science & Policy and Science Communications programs, and an artist in residence, among others. In a series of perspective pieces we will tell some of the stories of how their work drives innovation locally, nationally, and globally.

Source: Company Website

+ UC SANTA CRUZ ALUMNI LEADING LOCAL NONPROFITS: GREY BEARS

Late UC Santa Cruz alumna Kristina Mailliard (Cowell '74) founded Grey Bears in 1973. Grey Bears Development Manager Kayla Traber provides insight into the legacy of Mailliard and the continued impact Grey Bears has on the Santa Cruz senior population. Santa Cruz County is home to over a thousand nonprofit organizations, groups dedicated to strengthening the community, supporting those in need, and making a meaningful impact. Many of these nonprofits have roots that trace back to University of California, Santa Cruz alumni who played pivotal roles in launching and shaping their missions. Among those are one of Santa Cruz's most recognizable names-Grey Bears -founded by a UC Santa Cruz alumna and integral to the community's health and well-being.

Source: Company Website

+ UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA SANTA CRUZ: MEET YOUR 2025-26 ALUMNI COUNCIL

The University of California Santa Cruz Alumni Association is proud to announce its 2025-26 Alumni Council cohort, welcoming three new members to the Council and two members to the executive committee. The UC Santa Cruz Alumni Council is the volunteer governing board of the Alumni Association.

Source: Company Website

Activities

Tetra Tech, Inc. is a leading global provider of consulting and engineering services, headquartered in Pasadena, California. The company primarily generates its revenue from two core segments: Government Services Group (GSG) and Commercial/International Services Group (CIG). The GSG, which accounts for the largest portion of revenue, focuses on providing technical services to U.S. federal, state, and local government agencies, including water resource management, environmental restoration, and infrastructure support. The CIG segment serves commercial clients and international markets with similar expertise in water, environment, and energy solutions. Among its fastest-growing areas, Tetra Tech has seen significant expansion in renewable energy projects, particularly in wind and solar infrastructure, as well as climate resilience and disaster recovery services, driven by increasing global demand for sustainable solutions. With a strong commitment to innovation, Tetra Tech continues to address complex challenges in water, environment, and infrastructure for a diverse client base worldwide. It is the NASDAQ's 5th largest Consumer product/services company by market capitalisation.

urn:contentItem:6G8P-HS63-RYSR-R0MM-00000-00July 14, 2025: University of Kansas Cancer Center: Study finds cities with proactive, risk-tolerant governing styles most likely to have ambitious climate strategies2025-07-17T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T07:00:52ZLexisNexisANNOUNCEMENTSJuly 14, 2025: University of Kansas Cancer Center: Study finds cities with proactive, risk-tolerant governing styles most likely to have ambitious climate strategies

A new study led by two researchers with the School of Public Affairs & Administration at the University of Kansas finds that cities with proactive, learning-oriented and risk-tolerant governance styles are significantly more likely to implement ambitious climate resilience strategies.

The peer-reviewed article in the journal Climate Policy, titled "Do cities with greater transformative governance capacity pursue more ambitious policies? Examining U.S. cities through the lens of climate resiliency," analyzes survey data from 386 U.S. cities and introduces the concept of transformative governance capacity, or TGC, a behavioral framework emphasizing learning, proactivity and risk acceptance as key drivers of innovative local climate action.

The findings show that cities with higher TGC are significantly more likely to participate in the Federal Emergency Management Agency's Community Rating System, a voluntary program that incentivizes advanced flood risk mitigation beyond federal minimums. These cities not only join the program at higher rates but also achieve higher CRS scores - an indication that they implement more ambitious policies, defined in the study as efforts that exceed baseline regulatory requirements and proactively address long-term risks. This suggests that TGC is a strong predictor of local policy ambition.

urn:contentItem:6GDN-Y023-S178-R0GG-00000-00Housing resilience is 'a priority'2025-08-04T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T07:00:52ZLexisNexisTHENATIONPg. 5Housing resilience is 'a priority'Noah Yim

The federal government needs to take the lead in making housing more resilient as more homes face extreme weather due to climate change, the Productivity Commission argues.

Without action, the cost of this risk will balloon from $9bn a year to $35bn a year by 2050, its interim report on the transition to net zero emissions by 2050 reads.

"Failure to act will be a drain on productivity growth," the Productivity Commission has warned.

"Without adaptation, labour productivity losses due to increased workplace exposure to heat from a 3-4 degree increase in global temperatures are estimated to reduce economic output by between $135bn and $423bn cumulatively between 2023 and 2063 (2022-23 dollars).

"Australia's productivity growth may also suffer from the higher costs of responding to and recovering from disasters - adapting ahead of time can reduce impacts and save costs in the long run, freeing up resources for more productive activities." This would mean that beyond climate risks and mitigation being factored into new builds under the National Construction Code, -existing homes would have to be retrofitted with upgrades, the Productivity Commission states.

As such, the government should look for mechanisms to provide incentives in this direction, it adds.

"To build the resilience of the existing stock, government could identify mechanisms to: increase finance for retrofitting homes, such as by subsidising resilience upgrades for vulnerable households in high-risk areas; â€¦ support households to build back to a higher standard of resilience after a natural disaster; â€¦ improve the resilience of social housing, such as by committing to meet minimum resilience ratings; addressing barriers to landlord investment, such as by implementing minimum standards for rental housing in high-risk areas," the report reads.

The commission admits resilience rating requirements on rental homes will "impose significant compliance costs" and that any carrot-and-stick measures in the regulatory environment must pass a cost-benefit analysis.

The commission also suggests an expanded climate risk information database, a star-rating system of homes' climate resilience, a cross-jurisdictional agreement to take steps to improve housing resilience, and expanded responsibility for the Climate Change Authority to monitor and evaluate progress on housing resilience. The star-rating system "should be outcome-based, with ratings reflecting potential damages from climate hazards", the commission argues. "Ratings should account for location-specific climate hazards and the characteristics of a property."

urn:contentItem:6GB4-8N93-RRVX-64GN-00000-00Tas interests at their core2025-07-23T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T07:00:52ZLexisNexisOPEDPg. 14Tas interests at their core

While the final outcome of the 2025 Tasmanian State Election remains uncertain, another crucial political milestone occurred yesterday with the swearing-in of Tasmania's representatives in federal parliament. Among them, experienced Labor MP Julie Collins continues her service for Franklin, joined by three fresh but familiar faces - Rebecca White for Lyons, Jess Teesdale for Bass, and Anne Urquhart, who transitions from the Senate to represent Braddon. Independent Andrew Wilkie also returns to Canberra after being re-elected in Clark.

Together, this team carries the responsibility of speaking for Tasmania in a national forum that too often overlooks the unique needs of our island state. Their voices are vital - not just in debating legislation, but in shaping policy and funding decisions that can profoundly impact the lives of everyday Tasmanians.

From securing health and education funding, to championing regional infrastructure, housing solutions, and climate resilience, Tasmania's federal MPs must work to ensure our priorities are not lost in the noise of bigger mainland electorates. The balance of experience and renewal in this new federal cohort is promising. Collins's ministerial background brings weight, while White and Teesdale arrive with state-level leadership credentials and a deep understanding of their communities. Urquhart brings longstanding union ties and advocacy experience, now applied with a more targeted electorate lens. They must work collaboratively, regardless of political stripe, to get results, because Tasmania cannot afford to be a political afterthought. We face pressing challenges, from rising cost-of-living pressures to growing demands on health and aged care services, and the impacts of a changing climate on agriculture and coastal communities. Strong, united federal representation is a necessity, not a luxury.

Activities

Tetra Tech, Inc. is a leading global provider of consulting and engineering services, headquartered in Pasadena, California. The company primarily generates its revenue from two core segments: Government Services Group (GSG) and Commercial/International Services Group (CIG). The GSG, which accounts for the largest portion of revenue, focuses on providing technical services to U.S. federal, state, and local government agencies, including water resource management, environmental restoration, and infrastructure support. The CIG segment serves commercial clients and international markets with similar expertise in water, environment, and energy solutions. Among its fastest-growing areas, Tetra Tech has seen significant expansion in renewable energy projects, particularly in wind and solar infrastructure, as well as climate resilience and disaster recovery services, driven by increasing global demand for sustainable solutions. With a strong commitment to innovation, Tetra Tech continues to address complex challenges in water, environment, and infrastructure for a diverse client base worldwide. It is the NASDAQ's 5th largest Consumer product/services company by market capitalisation.

Total dividends per share paid in the 12 months ended August 01 were 19.26c. This reflects actual dividend yield of 0.5% at the last price of $36.74.

Press Release article 3 of 3, Source: Company Website, 291 words

August 22 2024: IAG releases Climate Action Plan

The Climate Action Plan includes IAG's updated FY30 emissions reduction interim targets and outlines how IAG is supporting the transition towards a low-carbon, climate resilient economy.

IAG Managing Director and Chief Executive Officer, Nick Hawkins said, "The need to act on climate change has never been more urgent and we're proud to play our part. Our Climate Action Plan demonstrates our commitment to helping customers and communities in Australia and New Zealand adapt to a changing climate and transition to a net zero future."

With the goal to become a net zero insurer by 2050, IAG is working to achieve net zero emissions across its operations, while actively strengthening climate resilience and capturing opportunities through the transition.

IAG's Climate Action Plan is focused on three key action areas:

1. Adapting its direct operations

IAG is focused on lowering scope 1 and 2 emissions to meet a science aligned 1.5C pathway and transitioning its direct operations to build climate resilience.

2. Supporting its value chain

Recognising that its influence extends beyond its immediate operations, IAG is using its knowledge and reach to help accelerate the transition to net zero across its full value chain, supporting customers, suppliers and partners.

3. Collaborating and advocating

Driving systemic change through its partnerships and advocacy work, IAG is supporting communities to build climate resilience and is sharing its understanding of climate risks and opportunities by partnering with governments, industry, and other organisations.

As detailed in the Climate Action Plan, IAG has updated its emissions reduction interim targets to net zero scope 1 and 2 emissions by FY30 from a FY24 baseline and it will also reduce limited upstream operational scope 3 emissions by 50% from a FY24 baseline.

urn:contentItem:6G5P-8VP3-RTDG-74WM-00000-00WEEKLY RECAP: UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA SANTA CRUZ NEWS THIS PAST WEEK JUL 01, 20252025-07-02T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T07:00:52ZLexisNexisWEEKLY RECAP: UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA SANTA CRUZ NEWS THIS PAST WEEK JUL 01, 2025

+ UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA SANTA CRUZ [8 Press Releases]

+ UC SANTA CRUZ ALUMNI AT THE FOREFRONT OF ALOPECIA RESEARCH AND ADVOCACY

Key takeaways Nicole Friedland (Merrill '89, community studies) is the President and CEO of the National Alopecia Areata Foundation. Brett King (Crown '92, chemistry) is a renowned dermatologist who discovered that a class of medicines called Janus kinase (JAK) inhibitors were effective for treatment of alopecia areata and other disorders.

Source: Company Website

+ EVENTS CALENDAR: UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA SANTA CRUZ FACULTY AND FELLOWS AMONG GLOBAL LEADERS IN ATTENDANCE AT 2025 UNITED NATIONS OCEAN CONFERENCE

On June 9-13, some of the world's top leaders in marine science and protection convened in Nice, France for the third United Nations Ocean Conference (UNOC). University of California, Santa Cruz and the Center for Coastal Climate Resilience (CCCR) had strong representation at UNOC and the opening Blue Economy Finance Forum (BEFF) in Monaco, with several fellows and faculty attending to share highlights from their research and engage in global dialogues about climate adaptation, mitigation and the future of our coasts.

Source: Company Website

+ UC SANTA CRUZ ALUMNI LEADING LOCAL NONPROFITS: THE VOLUNTEER CENTER

Santa Cruz County is home to over a thousand nonprofit organizations, groups dedicated to strengthening the community, supporting those in need, and making a meaningful impact. Many of these nonprofits have roots that trace back to University of California Santa Cruz alumni, who played pivotal roles in launching and shaping their missions. Among those are one of Santa Cruz's most recognizable names-the Volunteer Center of Santa Cruz County -which shares ties with many UC Santa Cruz alumni and is integral to the community's health and well-being.

Source: Company Website

+ UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA SANTA CRUZ: USING TECHNOLOGY AND GAMES TO BUILD CLIMATE RESILIENT COMMUNITIES

Technology enhances resilience by expanding access to information and strengthening community networks. Hirsch's research highlights the role of digital tools-like social media and messaging apps-in building preparedness and connecting people to local resources.

Source: Company Website

+ UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA SANTA CRUZ: UNDERSTANDING THE INFLUENCES OF TECHNOLOGY AND ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT ON GENOCIDE RISK

The rise of social media in recent decades has brought with it a steady drumbeat of warnings from experts around the world. The unchecked spread of disinformation, propaganda, and hate speech on these platforms can fuel the darkest of human impulses. New research led by politics and legal studies double-major John Bentley shows how the roll-out of social media in developing countries could actually increase the risk of genocide.

Source: Company Website

+ UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA SANTA CRUZ: THE FUTURE OF CLIMATE: THE CENTER FOR COASTAL CLIMATE RESILIENCE SUPPORTS A CRITICAL WAVE OF RESEARCH FELLOWS

As the science community's focus on climate change and adaptation continues to grow, research fellows are playing a pivotal role in driving the innovation needed to build greater resilience in the face of climate change. The University of California, Santa Cruz Center for Coastal Climate Resilience has made a major commitment in the past 2.5 years to support and bring to campus more than 60 Fellows at all levels from early career grad students to senior fellows. Fellows cover programs across campus and include business leaders, indigenous diplomats, graduate students in Coastal Science & Policy and Science Communications programs, and an artist in residence, among others. In a series of perspective pieces we will tell some of the stories of how their work drives innovation locally, nationally, and globally.

Source: Company Website

+ UC SANTA CRUZ ALUMNI LEADING LOCAL NONPROFITS: GREY BEARS

Late UC Santa Cruz alumna Kristina Mailliard (Cowell '74) founded Grey Bears in 1973. Grey Bears Development Manager Kayla Traber provides insight into the legacy of Mailliard and the continued impact Grey Bears has on the Santa Cruz senior population. Santa Cruz County is home to over a thousand nonprofit organizations, groups dedicated to strengthening the community, supporting those in need, and making a meaningful impact. Many of these nonprofits have roots that trace back to University of California, Santa Cruz alumni who played pivotal roles in launching and shaping their missions. Among those are one of Santa Cruz's most recognizable names-Grey Bears -founded by a UC Santa Cruz alumna and integral to the community's health and well-being.

Source: Company Website

+ UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA SANTA CRUZ: MEET YOUR 2025-26 ALUMNI COUNCIL

The University of California Santa Cruz Alumni Association is proud to announce its 2025-26 Alumni Council cohort, welcoming three new members to the Council and two members to the executive committee. The UC Santa Cruz Alumni Council is the volunteer governing board of the Alumni Association.

Source: Company Website

++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

urn:contentItem:6GDN-NY43-RRJW-133J-00000-00Housing resilience 'a priority'2025-08-03T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T07:00:52ZLexisNexisHousing resilience 'a priority'

Document links may not lead to an active page. Page maintenance is at the discretion of the publisher.

Noah Yim

The federal government needs to take the lead in making housing more resilient as more homes face extreme weather due to climate change, the Productivity Commission argues.

Without action, the cost of this risk will balloon from $9bn a year to $35bn a year by 2050, its interim report on the transition to net zero emissions by 2050 reads.

"Failure to act will be a drain on productivity growth," the Productivity Commission has warned.

"Without adaptation, labour productivity losses due to increased workplace exposure to heat from a 3-4 degree increase in global temperatures are estimated to reduce economic output by between $135bn and $423bn cumulatively between 2023 and 2063 (2022-23 dollars).

"Australia's productivity growth may also suffer from the higher costs of responding to and recovering from disasters - adapting ahead of time can reduce impacts and save costs in the long run, freeing up resources for more productive activities."

This would mean that beyond climate risks and mitigation being factored into new builds under the National Construction Code, ­existing homes would have to be retrofitted with upgrades, the Productivity Commission states.

As such, the government should look for mechanisms to provide incentives in this direction, it adds.

"To build the resilience of the existing stock, government could identify mechanisms to: increase finance for retrofitting homes, such as by subsidising resilience upgrades for vulnerable households in high-risk areas; ... support households to build back to a higher standard of resilience after a natural disaster; ... improve the resilience of social housing, such as by committing to meet minimum resilience ratings; addressing barriers to landlord investment, such as by implementing minimum standards for rental housing in high-risk areas," the report reads.

The commission admits resilience rating requirements on rental homes will "impose significant compliance costs" and that any carrot-and-stick measures in the regulatory environment must pass a cost-benefit analysis.

The commission also suggests an expanded climate risk information database, a star-rating system of homes' climate resilience, a cross-jurisdictional agreement to take steps to improve housing resilience, and expanded responsibility for the Climate Change Authority to monitor and evaluate progress on housing resilience.

The star-rating system "should be outcome-based, with ratings reflecting potential damages from climate hazards", the commission argues. "Ratings should account for location-specific climate hazards and the characteristics of a property."

Activities

Tetra Tech, Inc. is a leading global provider of consulting and engineering services, headquartered in Pasadena, California. The company primarily generates its revenue from two core segments: Government Services Group (GSG) and Commercial/International Services Group (CIG). The GSG, which accounts for the largest portion of revenue, focuses on providing technical services to U.S. federal, state, and local government agencies, including water resource management, environmental restoration, and infrastructure support. The CIG segment serves commercial clients and international markets with similar expertise in water, environment, and energy solutions. Among its fastest-growing areas, Tetra Tech has seen significant expansion in renewable energy projects, particularly in wind and solar infrastructure, as well as climate resilience and disaster recovery services, driven by increasing global demand for sustainable solutions. With a strong commitment to innovation, Tetra Tech continues to address complex challenges in water, environment, and infrastructure for a diverse client base worldwide. It is the NASDAQ's 4th largest Consumer product/services company by market capitalisation.

The ex-dividend date is Friday, August 15, 2025 and the record date is Friday, August 15, 2025 and it is payable on Friday, August 29. Total dividends per share paid in the 12 months ended August 01 were 19.26c. This reflects actual dividend yield of 0.5% at the last price of $36.74.

urn:contentItem:6G64-76Y3-RRRD-32JN-00000-00WEEKLY RECAP: HONG KONG UNIVERSITY OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY NEWS THIS PAST WEEK JUL 03, 20252025-07-04T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T07:00:52ZLexisNexisWEEKLY RECAP: HONG KONG UNIVERSITY OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY NEWS THIS PAST WEEK JUL 03, 2025

+ HONG KONG UNIVERSITY OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY [9 Press Releases]

+ HKUST CHEMISTS DISCOVER A "SUPER" PHOTOREDUCTANT TO LEAP FORWARD IN PHOTOCATALYSIS

Chemists at the School of Science of the Hong Kong University of Science and Technology (HKUST) have recently made a significant breakthrough in photocatalysis by unveiling a "super" photoreductant, marking a major advancement in organic synthesis.

Quantum dots (QDs) hold great promise as photocatalysts for promoting photoredox chemistry, however, their application in photocatalytic organic transformations has lagged behind that of small molecule photosensitizers due to the limited understanding of their photophysics. While various studies have explored the generation of hot electrons from QDs as a strategy to enhance photoreduction efficiencies, achieving effective hot-electron generation under mild conditions has posed a significant challenge.

Source: Company Website

+ HKUST UNVEILS OTTO POON CENTER FOR CLIMATE RESILIENCE AND SUSTAINABILITY

The Hong Kong University of Science and Technology (HKUST) today inaugurated the Otto Poon Center for Climate Resilience and Sustainability (CCRS), a transformative initiative designed to accelerate research, innovation and policy solutions in climate resilience and sustainable development. Established through the generous support of Ir Dr. Otto POON, Founder of the Otto Poon Charitable Foundation, the Center unites HKUST's world-class expertise in climate science, advanced modeling systems, artificial intelligence (AI), renewable energy and sustainable policy to deliver scalable and actionable strategies for governments, industries, and communities worldwide. Source: Company Website

+ HKUST HOLDS FLAG-RAISING CEREMONY TO CELEBRATE THE 28TH ANNIVERSARY OF THE ESTABLISHMENT OF THE HKSAR

The Hong Kong University of Science and Technology (HKUST) held a flag-raising ceremony on campus this morning to commemorate the 28th anniversary of the establishment of the HKSAR. Officiating guests included Mr. QIN Hong, Counsellor of the Policy Research Department of the Commissioner's Office of China's Foreign Ministry in the HKSAR; Dr. John CHAN, HKUST Pro-Chancellor; Ms. Edith SHIH, HKUST Council Vice-Chairperson; Prof. Nancy IP, HKUST President; and other senior management.

Source: Company Website

+ HONG KONG UNIVERSITY OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY: A DAZZLING NIGHT OF PHILANTHROPY: DR. JENSEN HUANG'S AUTOGRAPHED LEATHER JACKETS FOUND ITS WAY TO AN EDUCATIONAL CAUSE

The inaugural Gala Dinner of the HKUST Foundation recently took place amid an outpouring of kindness and generosity-hosting over 200 distinguished guests of academia, business, and philanthropy. The gala dinner marked the official launch of the HKUST Foundation, which aims to foster a greater sense of belonging among the University community while broadening its fundraising network for strategic development.

Source: Company Website

+ HONG KONG UNIVERSITY OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY: FUSING AI AND ROBOTICS: THE FUTURE OF SMARTER HEALTHCARE IS WITHIN REACH

Global healthcare is facing a wide range of challenges, including ageing populations and an increase in chronic diseases, which are putting immense strain on healthcare systems. The demand for advanced medical technologies like less invasive and more precise surgical tools has never been more urgent. The situation prompted a global wave of innovation in micro-scale medical robotics designed to assist clinicians with unprecedented accuracy and effectiveness.

Source: Company Website

+ HONG KONG UNIVERSITY OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY: "I AM AN HKUSTER" SERIES: FROM A STUDENT IN NEED TO AN ENTREPRENEUR GIVING BACK

Once a student from modest beginnings, Terry TSANG is now the CEO of Madhead, a leading mobile game developer. His smash-hit game, Tower of Saviors, has over 23 million downloads worldwide and features collaborations with top animation franchises. Despite his success, Terry remains deeply connected to his alma mater, HKUST.

Source: Company Website

+ "I AM AN HKUSTER" SERIES: FROM A STUDENT IN NEED TO AN ENTREPRENEUR GIVING BACK

Once a student from modest beginnings, Terry TSANG is now the CEO of Madhead, a leading mobile game developer. His smash-hit game, Tower of Saviors, has over 23 million downloads worldwide and features collaborations with top animation franchises. Despite his success, Terry remains deeply connected to his alma mater, HKUST.

As an Alumnus, Council Member, and Donor, Terry's devotion to HKUST is unwavering. What he treasures most in his office is a 20-year-old letter from HKUST-reminding him of when the University gave him emergency support during a family tragedy.

Source: Company Website

+ HKUST APPOINTED BY WHO TO LEAD REGIONAL CONSORTIUM ON DIGITAL HEALTH INNOVATION

The Hong Kong University of Science and Technology (HKUST) has been appointed by the Asia Pacific Observatory on Health Systems and Policies (APO), a collaborative partnership hosted by the World Health Organization (WHO)'s Regional Office for the Western Pacific, to spearhead a regional research consortium focused on digital health innovation. This prestigious appointment, secured through a competitive process, underscores HKUST's global leadership in policy research under the theme "Leveraging Digital Health Technologies and Data to Strengthen Health System Outcomes."

Source: Company Website

+ NAVIGATING THE SKIES: HKUSTS GAME-CHANGING DIGITAL TWIN

For many, sticking to familiar paths feels safe and comfortable. But not for the trailblazers at the Hong Kong University of Science and Technology (HKUST). They are not just thinking outside the box-they are pushing boundaries and aiming for the skies-quite literally.

Source: Company Website

Activities

Tetra Tech, Inc. is a leading global provider of consulting and engineering services, headquartered in Pasadena, California. The company primarily generates its revenue from two core segments: Government Services Group (GSG) and Commercial/International Services Group (CIG). The GSG, which accounts for the largest portion of revenue, focuses on providing technical services to U.S. federal, state, and local government agencies, including water resource management, environmental restoration, and infrastructure support. The CIG segment serves commercial clients and international markets with similar expertise in water, environment, and energy solutions. Among its fastest-growing areas, Tetra Tech has seen significant expansion in renewable energy projects, particularly in wind and solar infrastructure, as well as climate resilience and disaster recovery services, driven by increasing global demand for sustainable solutions. With a strong commitment to innovation, Tetra Tech continues to address complex challenges in water, environment, and infrastructure for a diverse client base worldwide. It is the NASDAQ's 4th largest Consumer product/services company by market capitalisation.

TETRA TECH PRESS RELEASES AND CORPORATE WIRE

August 01: Tetra Tech quarterly dividends steady

Tetra Tech today announced a quarterly dividend of 6.50c per share for Q3/2025; unchanged from the previous quarter (Q2/2025) dividend of 6.50c. The ex-dividend date is Friday, August 15, 2025 and the record date is Friday, August 15, 2025 and it is payable on Friday, August 29. Total dividends per share paid in the 12 months ended August 01 were 19.26c. This reflects actual dividend yield of 0.5% at the last price of $36.74.

urn:contentItem:6GJC-9SG3-S0CP-J2YH-00000-00August 06, 2025: University of Hawai i Sets New Funding Benchmark Amid Federal Uncertainty2025-08-21T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T07:00:52ZLexisNexisANNOUNCEMENTSAugust 06, 2025: University of Hawai i Sets New Funding Benchmark Amid Federal Uncertainty

The University of Hawaiʻi has achieved a remarkable milestone by securing extramural funding totaling $734 million for fiscal year 2025, marking the fourth consecutive year the institution has surpassed the half-billion dollar threshold. This announcement was made on 6th June 2025 and represents a significant increase of $118.3 million, or 19.2%, over the previous record of $615.7 million set in fiscal year 2024. The funding, which comes from various external agencies including the federal government, industry, and nonprofit organizations, supports essential research and training initiatives conducted by the University of Hawaiʻi's faculty and staff.

UH President Wendy Hensel emphasized the importance of this achievement in a time of growing concerns regarding federal research support. "This year marks another record-breaking milestone in federal support for the University of Hawaiʻi, highlighting the excellence of our researchers and our university system," Hensel stated. However, the backdrop of this success is troubling, as 66 grants worth over $89 million have been terminated due to shifting federal priorities. The anticipated cuts in federal budgets affecting major research funding bodies like the National Science Foundation and the National Institutes of Health add to the complexities of securing future funding.

The University of Hawaiʻi Manoa, the flagship campus of the UH system, led the way with $570.4 million in extramural awards. The UH System as a whole brought in $98.7 million, while UH Community Colleges, UH Hilo, and UH West Oʻahu contributed $31.3 million, $23.9 million, and $9.7 million, respectively. Interim Provost Vassilis L. Syrmos commended the UH Manoa research community for their significant contributions, noting that their dedication drives the university's research enterprise, which is vital for the well-being of both the state and the wider world.

An economic impact report from the University of Hawaiʻi Economic Research Organization indicated that research-related expenditures at UH reached $476.8 million in fiscal year 2020, contributing significantly to the state economy. This year's record in extramural funding reflects the university's ongoing commitment to addressing critical issues such as health disparities and climate resilience. Governor Josh Green emphasized the importance of UH as a key driver of innovation and economic resilience in Hawaiʻi. He stated, "This record-breaking year of research funding underscores UH's essential role in tackling our most pressing challenges."

Despite the positive funding news, stakeholders remain cautious about the future funding landscape. U.S. Senator Brian Schatz and other congressional representatives highlighted the need for continued support for the University of Hawaiʻi in light of potential federal funding cuts. As the institution celebrates its record achievement, the focus will be on navigating the challenges ahead to maintain the momentum of its research initiatives, ensuring that the university continues to play a pivotal role in the advancement of both local and global communities.

INDEX

SECTION 1 UNIVERSITY OF HAWAII SYSTEMS PROFILE

SECTION 1 UNIVERSITY OF HAWAII SYSTEMS PROFILE

1.1 ACTIVITIES

The University of Hawai''i System consists of three university campuses, seven community college campuses, and several job training and research centers. The public higher education system has an enrollment of more than 60,000 students, about 85% of which are Hawaii residents. It offers more than 600 different doctorate, graduate, undergraduate, and associate degrees, as well as professional certificates, in more than 200 fields of study. The University of Hawai''i was founded in 1907 as the College of Agriculture and Mechanic Arts in Honolulu, incidentally while Hawaii was still a US territory.

Activities

Tetra Tech, Inc. is a leading global provider of consulting and engineering services, headquartered in Pasadena, California. The company primarily generates its revenue from two core segments: Government Services Group (GSG) and Commercial/International Services Group (CIG). The GSG, which accounts for the largest portion of revenue, focuses on providing technical services to U.S. federal, state, and local government agencies, including water resource management, environmental restoration, and infrastructure support. The CIG segment serves commercial clients and international markets with similar expertise in water, environment, and energy solutions. Among its fastest-growing areas, Tetra Tech has seen significant expansion in renewable energy projects, particularly in wind and solar infrastructure, as well as climate resilience and disaster recovery services, driven by increasing global demand for sustainable solutions. With a strong commitment to innovation, Tetra Tech continues to address complex challenges in water, environment, and infrastructure for a diverse client base worldwide. It is the NASDAQ's 4th largest Consumer product/services company by market capitalisation.

Total dividends per share paid in the 12 months ended August 01 were 19.26c. This reflects actual dividend yield of 0.5% at the last price of $36.74.

Activities

Tetra Tech, Inc. is a leading global provider of consulting and engineering services, headquartered in Pasadena, California. The company primarily generates its revenue from two core segments: Government Services Group (GSG) and Commercial/International Services Group (CIG). The GSG, which accounts for the largest portion of revenue, focuses on providing technical services to U.S. federal, state, and local government agencies, including water resource management, environmental restoration, and infrastructure support. The CIG segment serves commercial clients and international markets with similar expertise in water, environment, and energy solutions. Among its fastest-growing areas, Tetra Tech has seen significant expansion in renewable energy projects, particularly in wind and solar infrastructure, as well as climate resilience and disaster recovery services, driven by increasing global demand for sustainable solutions. With a strong commitment to innovation, Tetra Tech continues to address complex challenges in water, environment, and infrastructure for a diverse client base worldwide. It is the NASDAQ's 4th largest Consumer product/services company by market capitalisation.

Total dividends per share paid in the 12 months ended August 01 were 19.26c. This reflects actual dividend yield of 0.5% at the last price of $36.74.

urn:contentItem:6G92-DPC3-RT2T-K05K-00000-00Take us to a stable future2025-07-18T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T07:00:52ZLexisNexisOPEDPg. 18Take us to a stable future

Just 14 months after the last state election, we are on track to return to the same parliamentary deadlock, and the same political uncertainty.

This cycle is not sustainable.

Democracy, at its best, delivers representation that reflects the will of the people. But it must also deliver function. Government exists to govern - not just to campaign, bicker, or stall.

Without a majority or a mature willingness to collaborate across party lines, the parliament risks becoming a chamber of gridlock rather than progress.

In that environment, stability becomes the first casualty, and the people of Tasmania are the ones who suffer most.

We cannot afford to keep rehashing the same election every year or so because leaders can't find common ground.

Polling conducted by EMRS on behalf of the Liberal Party shows the 2025 election likely returning a parliament similar to the one it voted in just 14 months ago.

If a minority government is again the likely result, then Tasmanians deserve firm assurances from those seeking to lead. Will they work constructively with the Greens and independents? Will they respect the mandates of crossbenchers elected by significant portions of the public?

Or will we again be dragged through another year of brinkmanship, instability and ultimately another early election?

The state faces real, pressing challenges - housing, health, cost of living, climate resilience - and those challenges won't wait for political egos to resolve themselves.

The public has done its job by turning out to vote tomorrow and in record early numbers.

Now it's time for elected representatives to do theirs. Work together, govern responsibly, and give Tasmania the stability it desperately needs.

Otherwise, we're doomed to keep circling the electoral roundabout. It's expensive, exhausting and utterly unproductive.

urn:contentItem:6GHX-03X3-RRSY-V18C-00000-00ClearVue deals solar facades into Middle East construction market2025-08-19T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T07:00:52ZLexisNexisClearVue deals solar facades into Middle East construction marketDoug Bright

ClearVue Technologies has signed a non-exclusive 5-year deal with a Dubai glass manufacturer, offering scalable production of its solar facade tech in the Middle East.

ClearVue Technologies has partnered with a Dubai-based glass manufacturer in a five-year deal offering scalable production to develop a Middle East market for its innovative solar façade technology.

The agreement gives Emirates Glass a non-exclusive licence to produce and distribute glazing products incorporating ClearVue's solar glazing innovations. Emirates Glass is a subsidiary of leading United Arab Emirates glass manufacturer Dubai Investments.

ClearVue's proprietary building-integrated photovoltaic technology converts standard building materials, such as windows, cladding and spandrels, into products that prioritise thermal performance while seamlessly integrating with a building's façade.

The company has established a low-cost, repeatable go-to-market strategy, leveraging global partnerships to drive demand. In July, ClearVue announced it was ready to take orders and deploy a full range of its breakthrough solar façade products, which promise to transform a glazed building into a solar photovoltaic array.

'Combining the Emirates Glass standing in the industry with the patented, proprietary advancements in solar technology from ClearVue is taking building sustainability to new heights in the UAE and beyond.'

ClearVue Technologies new chief executive officer Douglas (Doug) Hunt

The company's new chief executive officer Doug Hunt is leading a global commercialisation strategy, targeting climate resilience and net-zero goals through advanced solar glazing.

Hunt said Emirates Glass has a proven track record for the consistent delivery of large-scale, prominent projects and an established reputation for reliability, adaptability and modernisation with architects, developers and contractors.

Emirates Glass executive president Rizwanulla Khan said the two companies were aligned on sustainability goals and that his firm's scalable manufacturing capacity could support widespread deployment of building-integrated photovoltaics in the Middle East's building and construction sector.

The latest deal is part of ClearVue's commercial strategy to accelerate the development of its overseas manufacturing and distribution chains for its range of energy-efficient glazing and building products.

The company last month released the results of a comprehensive trial of its solar façade product in the headquarters of Hong Kong's Electrical and Mechanical Services Department. The trial tested ClearVue's innovative vacuum-insulated solar glazing unit developed in a strategic partnership with a subsidiary of advanced glass company LandGlass Technology.

The trial, which began in July 2024, suggests a 4.6-year payback period before subsidies for ClearVue's solar vacuum-insulated façade. When Hong Kong's feed-in tariff is included, the panels pay for themselves in 2.6 years.

The company applied the trial results to a hypothetical 40-storey building with a 50 per cent window-to-wall ratio, considering the local weather conditions in 15 cities.

The assessment showed ClearVue's integrated solar façade could offset between 74 per cent and 125 per cent of the building's annual energy requirements, advancing the path to net-zero buildings.

ClearVue's renewed executive team, led by its new CEO, is prioritising product optimisation and research to overcome adoption barriers. Along with achieving the increased energy and thermal savings demanded by modern construction, ClearVue is delivering technology that meets the relevant building fire and other safety standards, as well as modern design and architectural challenges.

Given Emirates Glass has a 400,000-square-foot facility and is known for supplying some iconic projects, the two innovative firms should be well-positioned to deliver sustainable construction in the region. That could mean a paradigm shift, where building façades generate renewable energy and improve a building's sustainability.

Is your ASX-listed company doing something interesting? Contact: mattbirney@bullsnbears.com.au

urn:contentItem:6GGN-YNN3-RS6H-50W1-00000-00All creatures great and expired2025-08-14T00:00:00Z2025-09-16T07:00:52ZLexisNexisNews3All creatures great and expiredSteve Evans

These birds can sound the alarm for our greatest threats.

An amazing new building containing literally millions of dead animals is to be officially opened in Canberra.

The Diversity building on the CSIRO campus cost $90 million and houses 13 million specimens of plants and animals.

They include 55,000 birds, 17,000 orchids, 2.4 million moths and butterflies and more than 7 million beetles - all making up a comprehensive picture for scientists to monitor how the Australian environment morphs over time and over the vast distances of our country continent.

Some of the specimens were collected 150 years ago and some of them were shot in the cause of science more recently. Either way, they now find themselves in the temperature-controlled vaults that are bushfire and pest-resistant in the shadow of Black Mountain in Canberra.

The specimens come from all over Australia and some were gathered more than a century ago. They vary in time and place so they can be compared.

This means that the scientists can track how species change over time and over distance.

And that means that if a new invasive species appears, for example, the CSIRO researchers can tell if it has been in Australia before. If it hasn't - if there isn't a specimen like it in the collection - the alarm bells start to ring.

"We have pests that are coming at our borders all the time and threatening our biosecurity , threatening our food safety, threatening our health, and it's often hard to know which of those species are new and which ones have been here for a really long time," Erin Hahn, conservation geneticist at the complex, said.

Two existing collections are now brought together in the building in Canberra, which neighbours the National Herbarium and the Australian National Tree Centre.

They form part of what is known as the National Research Collections Australia. The big CSIRO hub is in Canberra but the Australian National Algae Culture Collection and the Australian National Fish Collection are both in Hobart, and the Australian Tropical Herbarium is in Cairns.

In the Diversity building in Canberra, Dr Hahn stood next to trays and trays of dead galahs.

"These are species that you might see around Canberra, and they're just one of the many, many species that we have here in Australia which is one of the most biodiverse places on Earth," she said. "Each of these specimens is a precious record of the biodiversity that we have in a given area. One individual will tell you roughly what that species looks like, but having an array of them will tell you that diversity within a species."

The building was jointly funded by CSIRO and the federal government.

CSIRO's chief executive, Doug Hilton, said the facility would help monitor the environment, pests and weeds. It would help protect endangered species, prevent disease, and harness nature sustainably.

"For more than a century, our collections have quietly underpinned Australian science, policy, agriculture, biosecurity, and biodiversity conservation," Dr Hilton said. "This work contributes directly to the national interest. It informs biosecurity actions, climate resilience strategies, and land management activities."

Research scientist Erin Hahn and draws of galahs in a vault at the new building. Picture by Gary Ramage

Research scientist Erin Hahn and draws of galahs in a vault at the new building. Picture by Gary Ramage

Research scientist Erin Hahn and draws of galahs in a vault at the new building. Picture by Gary Ramage

Activities

Tetra Tech, Inc. is a leading global provider of consulting and engineering services, headquartered in Pasadena, California. The company primarily generates its revenue from two core segments: Government Services Group (GSG) and Commercial/International Services Group (CIG). The GSG, which accounts for the largest portion of revenue, focuses on providing technical services to U.S. federal, state, and local government agencies, including water resource management, environmental restoration, and infrastructure support. The CIG segment serves commercial clients and international markets with similar expertise in water, environment, and energy solutions. Among its fastest-growing areas, Tetra Tech has seen significant expansion in renewable energy projects, particularly in wind and solar infrastructure, as well as climate resilience and disaster recovery services, driven by increasing global demand for sustainable solutions. With a strong commitment to innovation, Tetra Tech continues to address complex challenges in water, environment, and infrastructure for a diverse client base worldwide. It is the NASDAQ's 4th largest Consumer product/services company by market capitalisation.

TETRA TECH PRESS RELEASES AND CORPORATE WIRE

August 01: Tetra Tech quarterly dividends steady

Tetra Tech today announced a quarterly dividend of 6.50c per share for Q3/2025; unchanged from the previous quarter (Q2/2025) dividend of 6.50c. The ex-dividend date is Friday, August 15, 2025 and the record date is Friday, August 15, 2025 and it is payable on Friday, August 29. Total dividends per share paid in the 12 months ended August 01 were 19.26c. This reflects actual dividend yield of 0.5% at the last price of $36.74.

Activities

Tetra Tech, Inc. is a leading global provider of consulting and engineering services, headquartered in Pasadena, California. The company primarily generates its revenue from two core segments: Government Services Group (GSG) and Commercial/International Services Group (CIG). The GSG, which accounts for the largest portion of revenue, focuses on providing technical services to U.S. federal, state, and local government agencies, including water resource management, environmental restoration, and infrastructure support. The CIG segment serves commercial clients and international markets with similar expertise in water, environment, and energy solutions. Among its fastest-growing areas, Tetra Tech has seen significant expansion in renewable energy projects, particularly in wind and solar infrastructure, as well as climate resilience and disaster recovery services, driven by increasing global demand for sustainable solutions. With a strong commitment to innovation, Tetra Tech continues to address complex challenges in water, environment, and infrastructure for a diverse client base worldwide. It is the NASDAQ's 4th largest Consumer product/services company by market capitalisation.

TETRA TECH PRESS RELEASES AND CORPORATE WIRE

August 01: Tetra Tech quarterly dividends steady

Tetra Tech today announced a quarterly dividend of 6.50c per share for Q3/2025; unchanged from the previous quarter (Q2/2025) dividend of 6.50c. The ex-dividend date is Friday, August 15, 2025 and the record date is Friday, August 15, 2025 and it is payable on Friday, August 29. Total dividends per share paid in the 12 months ended August 01 were 19.26c. This reflects actual dividend yield of 0.5% at the last price of $36.74.
